title: website
text:
This is a Quarto website. Isn’t that exciting? If you’d like to see a picture of me (Aviva) go to the “About Aviva Jotzke” tab. It’s awesome. You can also learn some information about me (Aviva) and some information about my professor (Nic Schwab).
To learn more about Quarto websites visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.
This is a link to my first map experimentation
This is a link to my first “fancy map” experimentation where I added markers to a map

title: About Aviva Jotzke
text: Aviva Jotzke is a junior majoring in Government and Statistical and Data Sciences at Smith College. When not studying, Aviva enjoys spending time with friends, going to concerts, watching the sky, and climbing (rocks and trees).

title: About Aviva Jotzke
text:
More fun facts
Aviva is exceptionally good at finding four leaf clovers.
Aviva does probably around 3 cartwheels a day.
Aviva has two younger siblings.
Aviva and from Des Moines, Iowa and is the Midwest’s strongest lover and defender.

title: 1st_Maps
text: Here are some maps from the map package. 1

title: 1st_Maps
text:
The US




































You try:
First maps

Add another map of California, Oregon and Washington.

Color this map. hint: type ?map() into the console to read the documentation.

Color the map with three colors of your choice.
Color the border only.


Make a world map with China, Indonesia and Australia.

title: Fancier Maps
text:
We can use leaflet to make some fancier maps.

#install.packages(leaflet)
library(leaflet)

Manual here Here is a text on leaflet.

leaflet()|>
  addTiles()





Let’s put Smith College on the map. Here’s the lat and long.

leaflet()|>
  addTiles() |>
  addMarkers(lng = -72.6403,
             lat = 42.3163,
             popup = "Home of the Pioneers",
             label = "Smith College")





Whooops. We need a negative sign to indicate west.

leaflet()|>
  addTiles() |>
  addMarkers(lng = -72.6403,
             lat = 42.3163,
             popup = "Home of the Pioneers",
             label = "Smith College")






leaflet()|>
  addTiles() |>
  addMarkers(lng = -72.6403,
             lat = 42.3163,
             popup = "Home of the Pioneers",
             label = "Smith College")





You try:

Put your home city and Smith College on the same map.


home_icon <- awesomeIcons()
school_icon <- awesomeIcons(icon="education")

#Created a map then added labels to it using first the addMarkers() function and then using the addAwesomeMarkers() function to give them home and school icons. 

leaflet()|>
  addTiles() |>
  addAwesomeMarkers(lng = -72.6403,
             lat = 42.3163,
             popup = "Where I go to school <3",
             label = "Smith College",
             icon=school_icon) |>
  addAwesomeMarkers(lng = -93.6250,
             lat = 41.5868,
             popup = "My hometown!",
             label = "Des Moines, Iowa",
             icon=home_icon)






Use awesomeIcons() to make your home look like a home and smith look like a college.

You will first need to save the icon an object. (Maybe the home is called home).
Hint: Use icon “education”, “book”, “sleeping” for the college icon.
Then you will need to use addAwesomeMarkers().

Finally add this webpage to your index.qmd and make sure it renders correctly.
